Test.JiraSummary: Multiple TrayZ and Maestro Smoke Test

TestStep.Action: Connect ${Num_TrayZ} TrayZ and ${Num_M2} M2 devices to Axis Z
TestStep.Result: # Devices are successfully connected # Relevant UI elements confirm the devices are connected and ready to use

TestStep.Action: Flashfirmware ${Flash_Firmware}
TestStep.Result: Firmware flashing is successful About window displays the correct version for all deviices

TestStep.Action: # Dock ${First Docking} then measure baseline and start recording # Dock ${Second Docking} then measure baseline and start recording # Import ImmunOncologyWithMajorGroups.implate for at least one plate for TrayZ
TestStep.Result: # Plates are successfully docked, baselines are measured successfully and recording begins # ImmunOncologyWithMajorGroups.implate was successfully loaded into the target plate and the Dose Response panel loads for the plate

TestStep.Action: During data recording create support bundle(s) for ${Support Bundle}
TestStep.Result: The correct number of support bundles are created Bundles contain logs for AxisZ and the relevant devices selected for the the bundle Example: * axis_z_logs folder with log files * axis_z_settings folder with settings files * Tray_Z bridge folder with log files for bridge requests log files, console telemetry CSV, console-axion log files * Maestro log folder with kirk logs, spock logs, enterprise logs, ngix access logs, init logs, subspace logs * SupportReport.log

TestStep.Action: While recording continues, Navigator is ${Navigator}
TestStep.Result: Data recording in AxisZ is not interrupted or corrupted

TestStep.Action: # While recording continues export notebook for the experiment with the dose response panel loaded # Open the notebook
TestStep.Result: # Notebook is exported successfully # Notebook opens in Excel without errors; # Table data and charts are correct ## Summary Settings ## Summary Series ## Summary Endpoint ## Summary Dose Response

Test.JiraSummary: TrayZ Continuity Plate Functionality

TestStep.Action: Set up the TrayZ device without any impedance plate docked and ensure it is in a functional state
TestStep.Result: TrayZ device is set up correctly

TestStep.Action: Load a Continuity plate into TrayZ
TestStep.Result: Continuity plate is loaded to TrayZ

TestStep.Action: Leave the Continuity plate idle for more than 10 minutes to capture at least two samples
TestStep.Result: As a Continuity plate is loaded into a TrayZ that doesn't have any other impedance plates loaded, it should begin impedance capture in less than 5 seconds

TestStep.Action: Connect AxIS Z to the TrayZ system
TestStep.Result: TrayZ device is connected

TestStep.Action: Send a GET request to the TrayZ bridge endpoint and record the number of retrieved samples or download imdb file via [http://localhost:5000/swagger/index.html|http://localhost:5000/swagger/index.html] Get endpoint and use EzPzDumperino or LiteDB to get samples
TestStep.Result: Number of samples retrieved after idly capturing impedance on a Continuity plate for >10 minutes = 1

TestStep.Action: Navigate to Experiment setup panel of the loaded Continuity plate
TestStep.Result: Barcode value in Experiment Setup Module should be in the following format: "Continuity Plate - \[x]"

TestStep.Action: Navigate to Plate Map Setup Panel of the loaded Continuity plate
TestStep.Result: TrayZ recognizes the new barcode as a 96-well impedance plate (similar to barcode 20)

Test.JiraSummary: Tray Check Impedance should care about Tray not Bridge

TestStep.Action: Open AxIS Z with 2 Tray devices connected to 1 bridge
TestStep.Result: * AxIS Z is opened * 2 Tray devices are connected (Maestro name is displayed as a dropdown field)

TestStep.Action: Open debug console (Ctrl+Alt+D)
TestStep.Result: Debug console is opened

TestStep.Action: Enter "listdevices"
TestStep.Result: All available devices are displayed

TestStep.Action: Enter "selectdevice \[id or SN]" for Tray 0
TestStep.Result: Tray #0 device is selected

TestStep.Action: Enter {{cmdtray FakeNextScan [basin #] [90 series plate #]}} → Dock the corresponding basin from the command (Don’t forget to {{cmdtray ClearFakeScan [basin #]}} each faked basin at the end of the test)
TestStep.Result: Smart plate for Tray #0 is spoofed

TestStep.Action: Enter "selectdevice \[id or SN]" for Tray 1
TestStep.Result: Tray #1 device is selected

TestStep.Action: Enter {{cmdtray FakeNextScan [basin #] [90 series plate #]}} → Dock the corresponding basin from the command (Don’t forget to {{cmdtray ClearFakeScan [basin #]}} each faked basin at the end of the test)
TestStep.Result: Smart plate for Tray #1 is spoofed

TestStep.Action: Select Tray #1 from the maestro name dropdown
TestStep.Result: Tray #1 is selected

TestStep.Action: Click Help → Check Impedance Signals !xray-attachment://d9a52caa-9578-4ebf-a2cc-b19a4c2421fe|width=345,height=252!
TestStep.Result: Checking device toast banner is displayed !xray-attachment://8789a329-8f98-408b-ab60-82ade3c391bd|width=1670,height=84!

TestStep.Action: Wait until check impedance signals test will be completed → Click Save Report → Save !xray-attachment://eeffe419-6125-4e9c-8aae-5bd514498c04|width=338,height=96!
TestStep.Result: Destination folder is opened, report is saved !xray-attachment://ea32ac35-5441-4d7e-90a4-9f3496ebfdec|width=371,height=42!

TestStep.Action: Open just saved report
TestStep.Result: * Report should *not* contain any impedance signal data from the Tray #0 * Report should contain result for the spoofed basin on Tray#1 * SN should be the same as Tray #1 has * Bay should be the same that was spoofed !xray-attachment://24108d93-4ac1-44c4-ae65-7a379834400f|width=1990,height=1386!

TestStep.Action: Reset AxIS.
TestStep.Result: AxIS closes and reopens.

TestStep.Action: Copy locally and add *OverwhelmingRatBrains.raw* into AxIS Add a Neural Offline Spontaneous configuration to the neural file. Can be found: Trunk\RAW Files\neural\OverwhelmingRatBrains.raw
TestStep.Result: Configuration added. Adds Three nodes: * Spike Detector * Burst Detector * Statistics Compiler

TestStep.Action: Double click the *Spike Detector* to Open the Spike Detector Settings. Check the settings. compare Settings to make sure knobs and default values are correct.
TestStep.Result: Done. Settings window appears. Knobs and default values are correct. See Screenshot

TestStep.Action: Double click the *Burst Detector* to Open the Burst Detector Settings. Check the settings. compare Settings to make sure knobs and default values are correct.
TestStep.Result: Done. Settings window appears. The new Network Bursts settings are: * Maximum Inter-Spike Interval = 100 ms * Minimum Number of Spikes = 50 * Minimum Participating Electrodes (%) = 35% Other settings and options are correct and match. See Screenshot

TestStep.Action: Double click the *Statistics Compiler* to Open the Statistic Compiler Settings. Check the settings. compare Settings to make sure default values are correct.
TestStep.Result: Done. Settings window appears. Settings and other options are Correct and Match. See Screenshot

TestStep.Action: Navigate to the *Experiment Setup Properties* and set up to Record: *Spike Detector:* * Spike Counts * Spike lists *Burst Detector:* * Electrode Burst List * Network Burst List *Statistics Compiler:* * Advanced Metrics
TestStep.Result: Done. Files have been set to record.

TestStep.Action: Press Record.
TestStep.Result: Done. 5 Files have been created.

TestStep.Action: Compare the csvs that were just recorded to the necessary files that are located at: \trunk\SoftwareTesting\JIRA Supplemental Files\NAV-3799
TestStep.Result: CSVs match.

Test.JiraSummary: Tray must run a UDP echo server

TestStep.Action: Open Debug Console (Ctrl+Alt+D)
TestStep.Result: Debug Console is opened

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘listdevices’
TestStep.Result: All connected devices are displayed

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘selectdevice \[Device ID / Serial]’ , replace device id or serial with the correct info from Tray
TestStep.Result: Tray is selected !xray-attachment://ec382c2d-f278-4b03-a72d-a7f75bf13a85|width=490,height=59!

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdtray DbgShowTelemetry’
TestStep.Result: At least one line should contain debug telemetry similar to "Count = 54651, Mark = 183, Basin = -1" !xray-attachment://15ed652c-7dbf-4beb-bcf7-482516dcc61f|width=426,height=77!

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘listdevices’ → Enter ‘selectdevice \[Device ID / Serial]’ , replace device id or serial with the correct info about Bridge device
TestStep.Result: Bridge is selected !xray-attachment://cf7c38a3-e93e-40de-b127-12fe08c31995|width=499,height=56!

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdbridge RunEthernetTest \[Tray serial #] 20 -b 1 -p 1400 -n 1000’
TestStep.Result: At least one line should contain info similar to this: _Test parameters: Interval=20ms BurstSize=1 PacketSize=1400 PacketsToSend=1000_ !xray-attachment://66ad6dc5-65fc-4db1-9927-bc6790ca3985|width=875,height=83!

TestStep.Action: # Open the Console tab on the bridge
TestStep.Result: Done !xray-attachment://ec172605-c3de-4431-aec1-221d4797429b|width=798,height=535!

TestStep.Action: Verify UDPEchoTest result from RunEthernetTest command is shown as Pass as long DetectedLost value is not greater than 1%. See image below !xray-attachment://2901d0c2-e87d-4330-a851-9a918de57cc4|width=577,height=75! !xray-attachment://a980e4fd-8ff9-45a3-887d-68d5ce88026e|width=567,height=185!
TestStep.Result: UDPEchoTest result is shown as expected

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdbridge selftest -r -w’
TestStep.Result: Success: Test Started !xray-attachment://d9170e43-9130-4165-ab16-b7a7522cabad|width=385,height=120! UDP test should pass if tray is physically connected

TestStep.Result: Support bundle is created

TestStep.Action: # Open .zip file # Navigate to the TrayZ bridge folder # Navigate to SelfTestResults # Open the last created SelfTestResults folder
TestStep.Result: +BridgeSelfTestResults.csv+ and +Tray++_\[TrayID]_++SelfTestResults.csv+ files are displayed !xray-attachment://7a00e1ab-447a-4cdd-a4a7-9735ae74c7df|width=1488,height=233!

TestStep.Action: Open Tray\[TrayId]SelfTestResults.csv file
TestStep.Result: File should contain Ethernet Connectivity Test with the appropriate results which should be Pass as long as DetectedLost value is not greater than 0.5% !xray-attachment://5f5402dd-57a1-4b59-822c-d5403cb26582|width=1626,height=339!

TestStep.Action: Disconnect tray physically
TestStep.Result: Tray is disconnected

TestStep.Action: # Open Debug Console (Ctrl+Alt+D) # Enter ‘cmdbridge selftest -r -w’
TestStep.Result: Success: Test Started UDP test should fail as tray is physically disconnected

TestStep.Result: File should contain timestamp of the test run and Barcode Scanner Connectivity Test with the appropriate results (Pass result)

TestStep.Result: Tray is selected

TestStep.Action: Type "selftest -r -w" on the bridge console
TestStep.Result: Barcode Scanner Test *fails*

TestStep.Action: # Navigate to Sos Tree tab # Expand SystemDiagnostics → BarcodeScannerTest
Navigate to AxIS Z → Create Support bundle via Help → Create Support Bundle

TestStep.Result: File should contain timestamp of the test run and Barcode Scanner Connectivity Test with the appropriate results (Fail result and Description with info about which scanners are failing)

TestStep.Action: # Scan the "Set factory defaults" barcode # Restart the tray (ex. via console bridge: _cmdbridge RebootTray 1_)
TestStep.Result: Tray is restarted

TestStep.Action: Type "selftest -r -w" on the bridge console
TestStep.Result: Success: Test Started AxIS Z will produce a record for the Barcode Scanner Test that *passes*

Test.JiraSummary: "Bay May not have closed" banner should not appear if plates are docking/undocking correctly

TestStep.Action: Make sure that all plates are docked
TestStep.Result: All plates are docked

TestStep.Action: Right click on Back Left basin → Eject Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully ejected No "Bay Back Left may not have opened" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Back Right basin → Eject Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully ejected No "Bay Back Right may not have opened" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Front Left basin → Eject Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully ejected No "Bay Front Left may not have opened" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Front Right basin → Eject Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully ejected No "Bay Front Right may not have opened" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Back Left basin dock icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be closed
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed ejected * "Bay Back Left may not have closed" banner is displayed * Back Left basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays ejected

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Back Right basin dock icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be closed
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed ejected * "Bay Back Right may not have closed" banner is displayed * Back Right basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays ejected

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Front Left basin dock icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be closed
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed ejected * "Bay Front Left may not have closed" banner is displayed * Front Left basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays ejected

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Front Right basin dock icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be closed
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed ejected * "Bay Front Right may not have closed" banner is displayed * Front Right basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays ejected

TestStep.Action: Right click on Back Left basin → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully docked No "Bay Back Left may not have closed" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Back Right basin → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully docked No "Bay Back Right may not have closed" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Front Left basin → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully docked No "Bay Front Left may not have closed" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Right click on Front Right basin → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: Plate is successfully docked No "Bay Front Right may not have closed" banner is displayed

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Back Left basin eject icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be opened
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed docked * "Bay Back Left may not have opened" banner is displayed * Back Left basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays docked as well

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Back Right basin eject icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be opened
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed docked * "Bay Back Right may not have opened" banner is displayed * Back Right basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays docked as well

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Front Left basin eject icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be opened
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed docked * "Bay Front Left may not have opened" banner is displayed * Front Left basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays docked as well

TestStep.Action: Tap on the Front Right basin eject icon directly on the device *and* prevent it to be opened
TestStep.Result: * Plate is stayed docked * "Bay Front Right may not have opened" banner is displayed * Front Right basin on an AxIS Z device icon stays docked as well

Test.JiraSummary: "Some wells are not being detected" toast message should appear as the baselining completes

TestStep.Action: Connect a TrayZ device with at least one plate with a large number of empty wells _(this should work with either an emulator or a real device)_
TestStep.Result: TrayZ is connected, at least one plate has a large number of empty/dirty wells

TestStep.Action: Open AxIS Z Select basin with a large number of empty wells → Dock if it’s undocked
TestStep.Result: Basin with a large number of empty wells is docked

TestStep.Action: Click Measure baseline button on the experiment panel → Wait until baseline will be completed
TestStep.Result: Baseline completed The "Some wells are not being detected" toast message +appears as the baselining completes,+ not in the second sample cycle after baselining

Test.JiraSummary: AxIS Z should not crash when TrayZ Bridge is restarted

TestStep.Action: Make sure that all plates are docked, if not → Right click on each basin and dock each of them in a sequence
TestStep.Result: All plates are docked

TestStep.Action: Disconnect/Close the Bridge
TestStep.Result: Bridge is disconnected/closed AxIS Z is not crashed AxIS Z device icon is changed to "No Maestro Connected" !xray-attachment://39d61443-c851-4e38-9f3d-acea0741144f|width=319,height=375!

TestStep.Action: Plug in / Open TrayZ Bridge
TestStep.Result: Tray device is connected to the AxIS Z and AxIS Z device icon shows 1 connected Tray device

TestStep.Action: Click Measure baseline button on a device icon → Wait until baseline will be completed
TestStep.Result: All plates are baselined

TestStep.Action: Disconnect/Close the Bridge
TestStep.Result: Bridge is disconnected/closed AxIS Z is not crashed AxIS Z device icon is changed to "No Maestro Connected" !xray-attachment://5bc6564c-bde6-4ca8-b302-f3f4c9247a4d|width=319,height=375!

TestStep.Action: Reconnect / Open TrayZ bridge
TestStep.Result: Tray device is connected to the AxIS Z and AxIS Z device icon shows 1 connected Tray device with 4 filled basins which are capturing samples

Test.JiraSummary: Bridge IO Expander Connectivity Self-Test

TestStep.Action: Open AxIS Z connected to v2 or higher bridge. V2 bridge had the IO Expander chip (U14). V4 boards use a different FTDI chip with more IO so they don't need/have the IO expander chip.
TestStep.Result: Done

TestStep.Action: Open Debug Console (Ctrl+Alt+D)
TestStep.Result: Debug Console is opened

TestStep.Action: * Enter ‘listdevices’ * Enter ‘selectdevice \[Device ID / Serial]’ replace device id or serial with the correct Bridge device info
TestStep.Result: Bridge is selected

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdbridge selftest -r -w’ Open the bridge console
TestStep.Result: Success: Test Started AxIS Z will produce a record for the IoExpanderTest *pass*

TestStep.Action: # Create Support bundle for the device # Open the latest SelfTestResults folder inside TrayZ<tray name>\SelfTestResults # Open BridgeSelfTestResults.csv
TestStep.Result: File contains timestamp of the test run and same output for the IO Expander test seen in the console !xray-attachment://15b26f52-74cc-473c-b065-2e2a40475b03|width=608,height=233!

Test.JiraSummary: Debug console should be able to abort an ongoing self-test

TestStep.Result: Debug Console is opened

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘listdevices’ → Enter ‘selectdevice \[Device ID / Serial]’ , replace device id or serial with the correct Bridge device info
TestStep.Result: Bridge is selected

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdbridge selftest -r’
TestStep.Result: Success: Test Started

TestStep.Action: Enter ‘cmdtray selftest -abort’
TestStep.Result: Executing `cmdtray selftest -abort` in the debug console should abort any self-test of a TrayZ device currently in progress, and report the abort success to the user

TestStep.Action: # Log in to the bridge # Navigate to [TrayZ Bridge API|http://localhost:5000/swagger/index.html] # GET the sosroot for a given Tray ID
TestStep.Result: The response body should accurately display the relevant test results for both completed and aborted tests that were executed

TestStep.Result: Support bundle is created

TestStep.Action: Click "Open Explorer…" button
TestStep.Result: Folder where support bundle was created is opened

TestStep.Action: # Open .zip file # Navigate to the TrayZ bridge folder # Navigate to SelfTestResults # Open the last created SelfTestResults folder
TestStep.Result: +BridgeSelfTestResults.csv+ and +Tray++_\[TrayID]_++SelfTestResults.csv+ files are displayed

TestStep.Action: Open Tray\[TrayId]SelfTestResults.csv file
TestStep.Result: File should contain timestamp of the test run and relevant test results for both completed and aborted tests that were executed

TestStep.Action: On TrayZ Console application → Ambient Light tab

TestStep.Action: On Ambient Light tab (wait a 30 seconds until system refresh information at UI level)

TestStep.Action: Go Console tab → Enter 'cmdtray ClearFakeLight'
TestStep.Result: AmbientFakeLight setting is reverted

TestStep.Action: On TrayZ Console application → Ambient Light tab
TestStep.Result: Verify IsOnlime = True, VisibleRaw, IrRaw and Lux values are greater than 10, Dark Mode = False , Screen On = True, Hibernatin = False since light sensor detects ambient light

Test.JiraSummary: Export audit trail for a Maestro device - Automated

TestStep.Action: Select Tools → Export Device Audit Trail.
TestStep.Result: Dialog pre-populates the file name as \{year-month-date}_\{Maestro type}(Maestro name)_Audit.zip. example 2022-12-11_Maestro-Pro(Maestro-274)_Audit.zip.

TestStep.Action: Save the audit trail and open the zip file.
TestStep.Result: Zip file name is \{year-month-date}_\{Maestro type}(Maestro name)_Audit.zip. example 2022-12-11_Maestro-Pro(Maestro-274)_Audit.zip Zip file contains: # \[Content_Types].xml # {{{year-month-date}_{Maestro type}-(Maestro name)_Audit.pdf}}. example 2022-12-11_Maestro-Pro-(Maestro-274)_Audit.pdf # Axion.cer # Manifest.xml # User.cer

TestStep.Action: Open {{{year-month-date}_{Maestro type}-(Maestro name)_Audit.pdf}} and verify content as follows: # Title = Device Audit Trail # Exported by <Domain Name of user who generated it> # Exported on <Date and time of the export> e.g Exported on Monday, August 31, 2020 at 8:50 AM # Note stating that all dates are stated in the local time of the PC that generated it: ## All dates and times are expressed in the local timezone of the computer generating this report. For this report the timezone is <Eastern Daylight Time> which currently has an offset from GMT of <-5> hours. # Serial number: <serial number> # Firmware version <firmware version>
TestStep.Result: Everything matches.

TestStep.Action: Verify there is a separate page(s) titled "Changes to the Device State" containing: # A two column table in which: ## Time of the change on the left column with dates in "g" format which localizes to `m/d/yyyy h:mm AM/PM` in the U.S. e.g 11/21/2022 10:47 AM ## Text description of the change in the right column. e.g "Hardware Revision changed from to 1.3.0.0" or "CO₂ Alarm Triggered - CO₂ alarm triggered\!"
TestStep.Result: Two column table is present Left column has date/time stamp in the right format Right column has text description of changes to the device !xray-attachment://d05fadee-1b2c-458c-b302-7989bc866398|width=682,height=581!

Test.JiraSummary: Email notification is sent to user when user is added to User Access list on Maestro Z App

TestStep.Action: Open AxIS Z with ${device} connected
TestStep.Result: Application opened and ${device} connected

TestStep.Action: Go to ${device} then click Device Settings, go to Maestro Z App tab
TestStep.Result: * Maestro Z App tab is displayed ** App Settings section is shown with Enable App and Default Upload toggles ** User Access section is shown if Enable App is on !xray-attachment://7300f4c7-ca6a-4a8b-b696-8fe83007a364|width=349,height=263! !xray-attachment://1e6c65f0-d48b-4248-bc13-8aa58cd9fd15|width=404,height=352!

TestStep.Action: Click Enable App toggle and Default Upload toggle to turn them ON if they are not on (If License Agreement pops up user click on Accept option)
TestStep.Result: * Toggles set ON * User access section is visible

TestStep.Action: Type user email address on "Enter User Email" field and click on "Add" button
TestStep.Result: User email added to User Access section

TestStep.Action: Email was sent to user email address provided
TestStep.Result: User get email notification indicating getting access to Maestro Z App for ${device}

TestStep.Action: User go to [https://maestroz.axionbio.com|https://maestroz.axionbio.com], and log in using ${platform} browser and credentials on User Access section
TestStep.Result: User is able to access Maestro Z App interface in ${platform}

TestStep.Action: User can see Maestro Z App main interface
TestStep.Result: * Maestro Z App is available. * User can see Maestro Z App interface and Overview, Charts, and Tables sections are visible

TestStep.Action: Go back to AxiSZ → on ${device} go to → Device Settings → Maestro Z App and remove user added during test from User Access section
TestStep.Result: Users removed from User Access on ${device}

Test.JiraSummary: Experiment data can been seen on Maestro Z App when access is allowed

TestStep.Action: On AxIS Z, select ${device}, go to Device Settings, and then to Maestro Z App tab
TestStep.Result: User Access section is displayed

TestStep.Action: Look for User's email, select it and click on Delete icon
TestStep.Result: Delete confirmation message pops up

TestStep.Action: Click on OK green icon option
TestStep.Result: * Delete confirmation accepted * User email deleted from User Access section

TestStep.Action: User refresh ${platform} browser from experiment
TestStep.Result: * User cannot see Maestro Z App interface from device access removed * User cannot see data from running experiments from device access removed

TestStep.Action: Go to ${device} → Device Settings → User Access settings and add user email again
TestStep.Result: User access restored

TestStep.Action: User refresh ${platform} browser from experiment
TestStep.Result: * User can see Maestro Z App interface from device access restored * User can see data from running experiments from device access restored

TestStep.Action: Go to ${device} → Device Settings → User Access settings and remove user email again
TestStep.Result: User access removed

TestStep.Action: User refresh ${platform} browser from experiment
TestStep.Result: * User cannot see Maestro Z App interface from device access removed * User cannot see data from running experiments from device access removed

Test.JiraSummary: Data on Tables tab from Maestro Z App is displayed and filters can be applied

TestStep.Action: On AxISZ, then go to ${device} --> Analysis panel and Plate Map Panel
TestStep.Result: Well Groups setup is shown and Analysis data is displayed as a graphic

TestStep.Action: Go to Maestro Z App main page → Click on Tables on page footer
TestStep.Result: * Title is "Resistance (Ω) at <time> hours" indicating amount of time Z App has been receiving data from live experiment * Table data is organized in to 5 columns with the following headers: Group – Mean – SEM – Wells – Type ** Group - Treatment + Amount ** Mean - Mean Endpoint value ** SEM - Standard Error of Means (SEM by default or STD - Standard Deviation, it depends on error selection) ** Wells - Assigned Wells ** Type - Control Type * Each column can be sorted in ascending and descending order

TestStep.Action: Crosscheck setup shown under Analysis Panel → Plate Map section on AxISZ against table displayed on Maestro Z App
TestStep.Result: Information displayed matches

TestStep.Action: Data displayed is sorted by default on Well Groups on AxISZ --> Plate Map Setup
TestStep.Result: * Data sorted by Well Groups setup

TestStep.Action: Click on Groups filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Group filter * Data sorted in Ascendant order

TestStep.Action: Click on Groups filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Group filter * Data is sorted according Groups naming in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Mean filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Mean filter * Data is sorted according Mean value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Mean filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Mean filter * Data is sorted according Mean value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on SEM filter (SEM by default or STD, it depends on previous error selection)
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with SEM filter (SEM by default or STD, it depends on previous error selection) * Data is sorted according SEM value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on SEM filter again (SEM by default or STD, it depends on previous error selection)
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with SEM filter (SEM by default or STD, it depends on previous error selection) * Data is sorted according SEM value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Wells filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Wells filter * Data is sorted according Wells value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Wells filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Wells filter * Data is sorted according Wells value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Type filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Type filter * Data is sorted according Type naming in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Type filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Type filter * Data is sorted according Type naming in descendent order

Test.JiraSummary: Maestro Z App main user interface

TestStep.Result: Data shared

TestStep.Action: Access to Maestro Z App URL: [https://maestroz.axionbio.com/|https://maestroz.axionbio.com/] using ${platform}

TestStep.Action: Click on "Experiment <ExperimentName>" drop-down menu on top left side of page

TestStep.Action: Select previous ${device} device from drop down options shown in Maestro Z App

Test.JiraSummary: Data on Tables tab from Maestro Z App is displayed and filters can be applied - Phase 02

TestStep.Action: On AxISZ, then go to ${device} --> Analysis panel and Plate Map Panel
TestStep.Result: Well Groups setup is shown and Analysis data is displayed as a graphic

TestStep.Action: Go to Maestro Z App main page → Click on Tables on page footer
TestStep.Result: * Title is "Resistance (Ω) at <time> hours" indicating amount of time Z App has been receiving data from live experiment * Table data is organized in to 5 columns with the following headers: Group – Mean – SEM – Wells – Type ** Group - Treatment + Amount ** Mean - Mean Endpoint value ** SEM - Standard Error of Measurement ** Wells - Assigned Wells ** Type - Control Type * Each column can be sorted in ascending and descending order

TestStep.Action: Crosscheck setup shown under Analysis Panel → Plate Map section on AxISZ against table displayed on Maestro Z App
TestStep.Result: Information displayed matches

TestStep.Action: Data displayed is sorted by default on Well Groups on AxISZ --> Plate Map Setup
TestStep.Result: * Data sorted by Well Groups setup * Data sorted in Ascendant order

TestStep.Action: Click on Groups filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Group filter * Well Group data order matches the order in Axis Z. (That order is determined when the platemap is created)

TestStep.Action: Click on Groups filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Group filter * Data is sorted according Groups naming in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Mean filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Mean filter * Data is sorted according Mean value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Mean filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Mean filter * Data is sorted according Mean value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on SEM filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with SEM filter * Data is sorted according SEM value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on SEM filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with SEM filter * Data is sorted according SEM value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Wells filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Wells filter * Data is sorted according Wells value in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Wells filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Wells filter * Data is sorted according Wells value in descendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Type filter
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Up indicator is displayed with Type filter * Data is sorted according Type naming in ascendent order

TestStep.Action: Click on Type filter again
TestStep.Result: * Arrow Down indicator is displayed with Type filter * Data is sorted according Type naming in descendent order

TestStep.Result: * Experiment Setup panel for every single basin is shown * App Upload toggle is ON

Test.JiraSummary: Lumos 48, & 96 well plate type match/mismatch

TestStep.Action: *Requires: 48 Well Lumos and 96 Well Lumos* Reset AxIS and connect a 48-Well Lumos.
TestStep.Result: Lumos is recognized by AxIS Navigator.

TestStep.Action: Load stim waveform trunk\SoftwareTesting\Lumos\48-Well_lumos.sswf.
TestStep.Result: 48-Well_lumos.sswf is loaded. Trigger button is enabled.

TestStep.Action: Trigger the stimulation.
TestStep.Result: Stimulation occurs as it appears in stim studio.

TestStep.Action: Stop the stimulation. Load stim waveform trunk\SoftwareTesting\Lumos\24-Well_lumos.sswf.
TestStep.Result: 24-Well_lumos.sswf is loaded. Trigger button is disabled. Tool tip says "Your connected lumos cannot run a stimulation created with your selected plate type."

TestStep.Action: Load stim waveform trunk\SoftwareTesting\Lumos\96-Well_lumos.sswf.
TestStep.Result: 96-Well_lumos.sswf is loaded. Trigger button is disabled. Tool tip says "Your connected lumos cannot run a stimulation created with your selected plate type."

TestStep.Action: Disconnect the 48 well Lumos and connect a 96 well Lumos.
TestStep.Result: New lumos is connected. Trigger button is enabled.

TestStep.Action: Trigger the stimulation.
TestStep.Result: Stimulation occurs as it appears in stim studio.

TestStep.Action: Stop the stimulation. Load stim waveform trunk\SoftwareTesting\Lumos\24-Well_lumos.sswf.
TestStep.Result: 24-Well_lumos.sswf is loaded. Trigger button is disabled. Tool tip says "Your connected lumos cannot run a stimulation created with your selected plate type."

TestStep.Action: Stop the stimulation. Load stim waveform trunk\SoftwareTesting\Lumos\48-Well_lumos.sswf.
TestStep.Result: 48-Well_lumos.sswf is loaded. Trigger button is disabled. Tool tip says "Your connected lumos cannot run a stimulation created with your selected plate type."

Test.JiraSummary: Resume baseline measurement with Tray Z after an interruption - Automated

TestStep.Action: Reset Plates for any going experiments
TestStep.Result: All Plates are displayed as teal solid outlined basins with no fill​

TestStep.Action: Dock All Plates (if any are ejected) by doing it in a sequence clicking on each Plate → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: Plates are docked and displayed as a solid outline with no fill​

TestStep.Action: Wait until baseline will be completed for Back Right and Back Left Basins
TestStep.Result: _Baseline completed. Please add cells._ banner messages are displayed for Back Right and Back Left Basins

TestStep.Action: Click on Measure Baselines button on a Tray Z icon
TestStep.Result: Toast updates with status of the two basins being baselined Toast displays the status for all 4 plates as complete, in progress, etc The time taken for the progress bars complete is consistent across the plates

TestStep.Result: * All plates are ejected and displayed as unfilled basins with dashed borders !xray-attachment://782bd329-f7e8-465d-9ad2-3746f1f614ed|width=22%! * All Active experiments gone from the left-side list * Toast is updated with status of the two plates where the baseline was aborted in 1-5 seconds after ejection !xray-attachment://21a0e736-6eec-4fb2-a848-69c860b70200|width=1605,height=505!

TestStep.Action: Dock All Plates by doing it in a sequence clicking on each Plate → Dock Plate
TestStep.Result: * All plates are docked * 2 Plates are displayed as filled basins (Back Left and Back Right) * Plates which were ejected before baseline was completed (Front Left and Front Right) - displayed as unfilled basins with solid borders * Front Left and Front Right basins do not have going experiments * Measure baselines button is available to be clicked on a Tray device icon

TestStep.Action: Select Front Left basin → Navigate to Experiment Setup Panel
TestStep.Result: Front Left basin has Measure baseline button on Experiment Setup Panel

TestStep.Action: Select Front Right basin → Navigate to Experiment Setup Panel
TestStep.Result: Front Right basin has Measure baseline button on Experiment Setup Panel

TestStep.Action: Click on Measure Baselines button on a Tray Z icon → Wait until it will be completed for each plate
TestStep.Result: * 2 baseline banners appear for Front Left and Front Right plates * The time taken for the progress bars complete is consistent across the plates * _Toast displays with Baseline completed. Please add cells._ banner messages are displayed for Front Left and Front Right plates when baseline completed * !xray-attachment://6e3efff7-cdde-4062-a738-bc29deb9a0ea|width=1674,height=223!

TestStep.Result: Data is plotted on the Plots (data that was collected in the last 10 minutes, there is should not be any old captured data)

TestStep.Action: Navigate to Analysis Panel of Front Right basin
TestStep.Result: Data is plotted on the Plots (data that was collected in the last 10 minutes, there is should not be any old captured data)

Test.JiraSummary: Connected to a network bridge, a remote user cannot flash firmware, rename trays, reset plates, or move plateholders

TestStep.Result: User cannot flash firmware

TestStep.Action: dock/undock each of the plates
TestStep.Result: User cannot move plates up or down. Cannot dock or undock plates

TestStep.Action: rename any of the trays connected to the bridge using the device settings feature
TestStep.Result: User cannot rename a tray Maestro name text box is disabled

TestStep.Action: reset any of the plates
TestStep.Result: User cannot reset any of the plates

Test.JiraSummary: Connected to a network bridge, a remote user starts an experiment, uses the debug command, edits experiments and other actions

TestStep.Action: # Connect AxisZ to a networked bridge, select a tray on that bridge and start an experiment
TestStep.Result: Baseline is completed and impedance samples are collected

TestStep.Action: With Basin 0 docked, open the Axis Z debug console and execute these commands: * listdevices * cmdbridge GetTrayName * cmdtray MoveMotor 0 0 * cmdtray MoveMotor 0 1
TestStep.Result: Commands execute without errors and return expected result The plate holder for basin 0 is undocked The plate holder for basin 0 is docked

TestStep.Action: Edit a public experiment by changing an analysis setting
TestStep.Result: Analysis setting is saved

TestStep.Action: Export an experiment and open the exported experiment
TestStep.Result: Export is successful and the experiment opens without errors and displays the experiment without corrupted or modified data

TestStep.Action: Export and view a support bundle for the connected bridge
TestStep.Result: Bundle is created and contents are correct Contents include # axis_z_logs folder with axis log files # axis_z_settings folder with user and application settings files # SosDump.log # SupportReport.log # TrayZ_<tray name> folder with: ## SelfTestResults folder IF tests have been run on the bridge ## bridge-requests-JSON log files ## console-axion log files ## console-telemetry-tray csv files for each connected tray ## tray<#>-axion log files for each connected tray

Test.JiraSummary: Devices are shown as Connected/Network Devices under Selected Maestro on AxISZ, no heading option shown if no devices

TestStep.Result: "Networked Devices" is not shown and no networked devices are shown. "Connected Devices" heading is not shown Only directly connected devices are shown

TestStep.Result: Done.

Test.JiraSummary: Verify rules for two users making changes to network bridge experiment

TestStep.Action: * Log into two machines with the network bridge selected, one machine being the local one
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: Start a public experiment on the local machine (User A)
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Result: User B sees the changes a few seconds later

TestStep.Result: User A’s changes do not get updated on User B while User B is editing

TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: Verify that if User B cancels then User A’s changes get applied to user B
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: Verify that if User B applies changes AFTER user A then User A gets updated with User B’s changes
TestStep.Result: Done.

Test.JiraSummary: When basin is ejected while baseline, measurements stop and experiments are deleted

TestStep.Result: # After baseline measurement has started: ## tray screen button updates with solid background and experiment name and duration indicating baseline measurement started ## Toast displays in Axis Z that baseline measurement is underway # After the plate is ejected: ## Plate Holder (basin) is ejected in the tray ## Tray screen button displays "Dock" ## Axis Z UI displays dashed boarder for the plate in the tray icon

Test.JiraSummary: When baseline fails, Tray screen must show Measure Baseline button plate error

TestStep.Action: Verify the following: * Tray’s screen Measure Baseline button goes back in original state. * Basins for which baseline failed are in an error state, by having red border with two lines of text inside: barcode and "Baseline failed" or "Failed: Retry baseline"
TestStep.Result: * "Start" gray/white buttons is shown instead timer * Basins are showing error state

Test.JiraSummary: If baseline is running on TrayZ device and it's disconnected from AxISZ system, baseline process must continue

Test.JiraSummary: Impedance data recording must continue after baseline finishes, paused when basin is ejected and resume when docked

TestStep.Action: Open AxISZ on PC directly connected to TrayZ device, make sure basins on TrayZ device are docked and having at least one Plate Holder (basin) no baselined yet, then press Start button from Tray’s screen to start "Measure Baseline" process, wait until baseline is done successfully.

TestStep.Result: Impedance data recording is interrupted since basin is ejected

TestStep.Action: Dock basin back from eject state
TestStep.Result: Impedance data recording must resume right after basin is docked

Test.JiraSummary: When any action that interrupts normal impedance data capture will cause stopping baseline process and delete experiments

TestStep.Result: Check Impedance Signal is not available since Baseline process is active and running

TestStep.Result: Restoring firmware process completed.

Test.JiraSummary: UI elements and firmware verification for all device(s) connected to AxIS Z

TestStep.Action: Open AxIS Z with connected devices like Maestro, local tray and/or a network tray
TestStep.Result: Done

TestStep.Action: Click Help menu option and Hover over Create support bundle
TestStep.Result: * Each connected device (local and network) and "All Maestros" is listed in the submenu so that if desired the user can create a support bundle for each device independently or as a group * In this example a local Maestro, local tray and a networked tray display as expected. Your results may vary depending on the connected devices but, *all should display* in the sub-menu !xray-attachment://ae64d054-927f-4db2-9f07-184348241f0b|width=577,height=239!

TestStep.Action: Choose About option
TestStep.Result: For each connected Maestro the following should display below the version information: * <Device name> * SN: <correct serial number> * Device ID: <correct device id number> * Hardware: < correct hardware version> * BioCore: <correct biocore version> * Firmware: <version number> For each connected bridge/tray whether local or networked the following should display below the version information: * <Tray name> * SN: <correct tray serial number> * Device ID: <correct device id number> * Hardware: <correct tray hardware number> * Firmware: <correct tray firmware> * Bridge SN: <correct serial number for the bridge> !xray-attachment://1d461cfb-6d7b-4ead-b24d-a7b4a2c0179b|width=437,height=816!

TestStep.Action: Click Help → Restore Firmware
TestStep.Result: * "Update Firmware Confirmation" dialog is displayed with a list of All connected Tray Z devices and Maestros * Single checkbox exists for each tray including the remote trays. The listing for each tray should be unified, and use the text: _"Tray \[Tray 1 name] & Tray \[Tray 2 name] (Bridge # \[Bridge serial number])"_ if there are 2 trays connected to 1 bridge * Single checkbox for a connected Maestro with the correct name * Each checkbox should be enabled e+xcept for remote trays+. Checkboxes for the local devices will be empty or filled based on the version of the firmware being confirmed. * Checkboxes for all *remote* trays should be disabled and empty * Hovering over the checkbox for any remote tray should display a tooltip "You cannot update firmware on this remote device" !xray-attachment://8b34487f-7124-4312-9d65-cc4cea0ac5c4|width=461,height=407!

TestStep.Action: Check all the local Tray Z devices and Maestros → Proceed → Close Wait for the firmware update process to complete and for Axis Z to reopen
TestStep.Result: * Any remote tray cannot be checked * Devices are flashed in sequence * Firmware on all the checked Tray Z devices is updated * There is no Update Firmware banner after Axis Z opens

TestStep.Action: Wait until all devices are connected → Click Help → About
TestStep.Result: All devices display their information (no device failed to connect to Axis Z) Firmware version of devices is correct

TestStep.Action: Launch OffAxis with no File loaded.
TestStep.Result: The raster panel is empty except for a text in the center reading 'No Wells Selected'.

TestStep.Action: Restart the application multiple times with no file loaded
TestStep.Result: The raster panel is empty except for a text in the center reading 'No Wells Selected'.

Test.JiraSummary: Effect of Changing column Count on raster Arrangement

TestStep.Action: Change the column count from the default value to a positive numeric value and observe the rearrangement of rasters in the panel.
TestStep.Result: * The arrangement of the raster panel updates to match the new column count. * Rasters in the panel will be redistributed amongst the updated number of columns as evenly as possible. This may change the number of rows in the raster panel. * The order of rasters is maintained

TestStep.Action: # Change the column count to a value < 1 # Change the column count to a non-numeric value
TestStep.Result: * In all three cases, the column count is reset to the previous ‘good’ value e.g. the column count is not changed * Rasters in the panel will be redistributed amongst the updated number of columns as evenly as possible. This may change the number of rows in the raster panel. * If the column count exceeds the well count, there will be blank columns on the right hand side of the plot * The order of rasters is maintained

Test.JiraSummary: Empty Raster Module Window Selector and Text Boxes Behavior with Loaded File but No Selected Wells

TestStep.Action: Launch OffAxis with a loaded File but no Wells selected.
TestStep.Result: Window selector is empty, and start/end text boxes are empty and disabled.

Test.JiraSummary: Empty Raster Module Well List Is Empty on Application Launch with Loaded File

TestStep.Action: Launch OffAxis with a File loaded.
TestStep.Result: The Well list is empty except for a piece of text in the very center reading ‘No Wells Selected’.

Test.JiraSummary: Raster Visualization: Pip color, X-span and Well label

TestStep.Result: # The color of the raster pip should be Axion Teal # The X-span of the raster (the time the raster covers) should be limited to that determined by the user in Window Selection # The Well Label that corresponds to each raster should appear as a label in the top-left corner of the raster

TestStep.Action: In the Window selection, modify the time span for the raster
TestStep.Result: The X-span of the raster matches the user setting

Test.JiraSummary: Raster Panel Visualization Arranging Multiple Rasters in the Grid

TestStep.Action: Select multiple wells in the panel
TestStep.Result: * Selecting multiple wells should arrange the rasters in as uniform a grid as possible, adhering to a defined ‘column count’. * If there are more rasters than the column count, excess rasters should appear on a new row !xray-attachment://dc839b5e-3bb8-4a29-a5db-5e77b0369fbb|width=548,height=23! !xray-attachment://4fe84b1b-3447-4378-aa21-ccd13b91f171|width=458,height=458!

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: File → Quit option exists and is enabled.

TestStep.Action: Import a large spike file.
TestStep.Result: File -> Quit menu option is disabled for at most 5 seconds while importing the .SPK file. _(Spikepocalypse is a good test of a .SPK file large enough to observe this disabling behavior.)_

TestStep.Action: Click on File → Quit.
TestStep.Result: OffAxIS closes.

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: Last selected experiment should automatically be re-selected.

TestStep.Action: Click on X on top-right of window to close OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: OffAxIS closes.

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: Last selected experiment should automatically be re-selected.

Test.JiraSummary: Test OffAxIS creates workspace folder when opened and creates subfolder when a .spk file is imported

TestStep.Action: * Close OffAxIS if open. * Delete workspace folder. (C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace)
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: OffAxis creates a new workspace folder.

TestStep.Action: Import a spike file via File → Open .spk File…
TestStep.Result: * OffAxIS creates a new folder structure in the workspace. ** Ex: \{workspace}/\{barcode}/\{recording-time}/ * Files created inside the workspace ** original-spike-file.spk ** platemap.json ** mappings.json ** many \{recording-time}-spikes.esi files

Test.JiraSummary: Test When a .spk file is loading, OffAxIS should display a 'busy' spinner to indicate activity, then display name in tittle bar

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS.
TestStep.Result: * OffAxIS application name and version appear in the window title bar.

TestStep.Action: Import a .spk file via File → Open .spk File…
TestStep.Result: * While importing the file, OffAxIS displays the file name along with a busy indicator (animated progress bar) at the top of the side bar on the left of the window. * The progress bar is set to 100% as it is not known how long the import will take.

TestStep.Action: Place the mouse cursor over the busy indicator.
TestStep.Result: The tooltip for the busy indicator should say: "Importing \{file-name}".

TestStep.Action: File is done loading.
TestStep.Result: * The busy indicator is replaced by the newly imported experiment at the top of the list. * When a recording is rendered OffAxIS title includes recording name (along with app name and version).

TestStep.Action: Import a second spk file.
TestStep.Result: * The newly imported file is placed at the top of the side bar list. * OffAxIS title includes the name of the newly imported file, not the old one.

TestStep.Action: Add more spike files and/or decrease the side of the application window so that all the spike files listed don’t fit in the side bar.
TestStep.Result: A scroll bar is added to the sidebar to be able to see all the items.

Test.JiraSummary: Well Selection and Display of Raster

TestStep.Action: View the well list and select one well from the list
TestStep.Result: A raster corresponding to the selected well appears immediately in the raster panel.

Test.JiraSummary: Clearing Well Selection from the Raster View

TestStep.Action: Select several wells from the list then click the "Clear" button
TestStep.Result: # The raster panel updates clearing the wells and the rasters

TestStep.Action: # Select several wells from the list then click on a few of the wells just selected # Continue selecting wells in this manner until all selected wells are no longer selected
TestStep.Result: # The raster panel displays a plot for each selected # As wells from the selection are clicked (deselecting them from the list) the raster for that/those wells is removed from the panel # When a raster ‘disappears’, the rasters to the right or below it in the raster panel should shift to fill the ‘gap’. This may mean rasters from lower rows move ‘up’, or that there are fewer rows than before. # The order of the rasters is maintained throughout the selection and deselection process. E.g. A1, A2, A3, B1, B2, B3, C1, C2, C3, etc. # When all wells have been deselected the raster panel is empty

TestStep.Action: # Select all of the wells in the list then deselect all of the wells slowly # Select all of the wells in the list then deselect all of the wells quickly
TestStep.Result: The application performance does not degrade when the maximum number of wells is selected.

Test.JiraSummary: Updating the Selected Plot Types in the Raster View

TestStep.Action: # Open OffAxis # View the Raster Comparer module # Select a few wells
TestStep.Result: * The Header panel that houses the ‘column count’ textbox should also contain two buttons "Show Raster" and "Show Histogram" * Default state is for "Show Raster" is on "Show Histogram" is toggled off * Rasters display for selected wells * No histogram displays for any of the wells

TestStep.Action: # Toggle the "Show Raster" off and on and observe the Raster plots # Toggle the "Show Histogram" on and off and observe the Raster plots.
TestStep.Result: * When "Show Raster" is off, raster plots should disappear from all selected WellRasterviews. * When "Show Histogram" is off, histogram plots should disappear from all selected WellRasterviews. * When either toggle is on, that plot should appear in all of the rasters * When both toggles are on, the histogram should display on top of the raster plot in all of the rasters * When neither option is on the panels are empty except for a label ‘No Plot Type Selected’ !xray-attachment://1e3eba83-a2e8-483f-bd7c-33ac402b2b30|width=1054,height=341! !xray-attachment://e49b2e08-bfa0-4a64-9f0c-efa3a3223b9d|width=1086,height=567! !xray-attachment://c0dcbc1f-935f-423a-8c40-6640b218fc4b|width=1153,height=471! !xray-attachment://28865ff9-ca75-46f1-9e0d-855a706e8521|width=1198,height=553!

TestStep.Action: # Select all of the wells # Quickly toggle "Show Raster" and "Show Histogram" back and forth between on and off
TestStep.Result: * The plots update appropriately after each setting is toggled off and on * Performance is not degraded by rapid toggling between states

TestStep.Action: # Toggle "Show Raster" off and Show Histogram on then close and reopen OffAxis # Toggle "Show Raster" on and "Show Histogram" off then close and reopen OffAxis # Toggle both off then close and reopen OffAxis
TestStep.Result: Every time the application opens, both "Show Raster" and "Show Histogram" are on. {color:#ff5630}Changes made by the user are not persisted. In the next iteration, we'll implement persistence.{color}

TestStep.Action: Open OffAxIS and click on Help → Create Support Bundle.
TestStep.Result: Support bundle created. * It should make a bundle, zip it, and open a desktop windows explorer window. * The bundle should contain the logs from your OffAxis logs folder, * The names of things should make sense.

Test.JiraSummary: Sliding Window Selection in the Raster View

TestStep.Action: Load a spike file and select one or more wells
TestStep.Result: * Raster displays for the selected wells * Two cursors should be present on the window selector * The sliding window chooses the first selected well as a 'preview', then applies the window to all rasters for selected wells * The start cursor should default to the beginning of the window selector. There is no offset, the start cursor is exactly at the beginning of the selector * The end cursor should default to the end of the window selector. There is no offset, the end cursor is exactly at the beginning of the selector * The cursors are easily visible against the window selector. * The cursors are white, or ‘inverse’ colors of their background. * The cursors have ‘anchors’ on the top or bottom (or top for start, bottom for end) to allow the user to ‘grab’ the cursor easily and drag it elsewhere. * Below the window selector, there are two labelled text boxes: Window Start and Window End !xray-attachment://7c260ec1-a282-4288-b467-c6ed946ef449|width=1252,height=210!

TestStep.Action: Move the start cursor then move the end cursor
TestStep.Result: * Moving either cursor should update all visible rasters in the raster panel, modifying their start or end time to match the new position of the cursor. * The "Window Start" and "Window End" text boxes update with the offset time (in seconds) from the start of the file

TestStep.Action: Move the start and the end cursor very quickly without overlapping each other
TestStep.Result: Rasters do not update while the cursor is moving The start/end text box updates in real time in synchrony with the cursor movement The raster updates immediately after the cursor stops moving

TestStep.Action: # Move the start cursor past the end cursor # Move the end cursor past the start cursor # Make the end cursor and the start cursor overlap exactly # Swap the roles repeatedly
TestStep.Result: * Moving the start cursor past the end cursor or moving the end cursor past the start cursor will swap the roles of each cursor, so the start cursor becomes the end cursor, and the end cursor becomes the start cursor. * Rapid swapping of cursors due to quick movements does not lead to inconsistent states. * Swapping the roles repeatedly does not cause performance issues or delays. * Cursors swap roles correctly if they overlap exactly.

TestStep.Action: # Edit the "Window Start" text box with a new value and observe the position of the end cursor. ## Repeat the step trying to set the start time after the end time # Edit the "Window End" text box with a new value and observe the position of the end cursor. ## Repeat the step trying to set the end time before the start time
TestStep.Result: * The corresponding cursor should move to the position corresponding to that seconds offset from the start of the file * Must not be able to set the Window Start to be after the Window End or set the Window End to be before the Window Start

Test.JiraSummary: Off-Axis Log Files are Archived

TestStep.Action: Over the course of 15 days or by using the widget to change the date open OffAxis one or more times per day
TestStep.Result: Done

TestStep.Action: Open the folder {{%appdata%/Roaming/Axion Biosystems}}.
TestStep.Result: * The off-axis.log file is archived each day. Name is "off-axis.<yyyy-mm-dd>.zip" * The off-axis-structured-log.json file is also archived each day. It is named "off-axis-structured-log.<yyyy-mm-dd>.zip" * There is a 14-day limit for the log files. Meaning there should be no more than 14 daily log files stored in the folder along with the current day’s log files * The oldest log archive should be deleted so that no more than 14 archives are created.

Test.JiraSummary: Test Offset Setting for Raster File Alignment

TestStep.Action: # Load an experiment with multiple .SPK files # Select a few wells for each file # Observe the raster for each SPK file
TestStep.Result: Each file’s group box should contain a text box, labelled ‘Offset’, which allows the user to set the file’s relative offset compared to the other files in the experiment. Each offset is 0 by default if it has not been modified in a prior session !xray-attachment://1aa15ab9-132c-434a-921e-6ef46d84776d|width=1494,height=979!

TestStep.Action: Enter a valid integer as the offset for one file
TestStep.Result: The value is accepted and displayed in the text box No other offset is modified

TestStep.Action: Enter a valid integer for +_all but one_+ other offset in the experiment
TestStep.Result: * The value is accepted * No other offset is modified * The one offset not changed remains '0', the default

TestStep.Action: Edit the one offset from 0 to a valid integer
TestStep.Result: All files’ offsets are reduced by the smallest offset value, making at least one file’s offset 0 again

TestStep.Action: Change the offset value for each file in the experiment again and observe the changes
TestStep.Result: Offsets are adjusted consistently and correctly so that one file (the one with the smallest value) is reset to 0 In other words: the smallest value is subtracted from _all_ values.

TestStep.Action: Enter these invalid entries in one or more offsets: # negative value # letters # Decimal value
TestStep.Result: Those are invalid values so there is a warning/error message about each of them

TestStep.Action: Set offsets so that at least one is 0 and one is set beyond its stop time
TestStep.Result: The that ends before the time window displays the correct portion in the window

TestStep.Action: Set offsets so that at least one is 0 and one file is completely outside of the window
TestStep.Result: The raster does not appear for the file that is completely outside of the window

TestStep.Action: Remove one of the files
TestStep.Result: Offsets display correctly for the remaining file(s)

TestStep.Action: Add a file
TestStep.Result: Offsets display correctly for each of the files The offsets for the new file(s) is 0 unless they have been edited previously

Test.JiraSummary: Edge cases for the Mult-File Raster Module

TestStep.Action: A file starts or ends +*_very close_*+ to the start or stop cursor
TestStep.Result: It is not difficult to visually discern the end of the raster data and the beginning of the empty portion.

TestStep.Action: A file starts or ends at an exact cursor position
TestStep.Result: No display glitches where the raster data and the empty portion meet.

TestStep.Action: Multiple files stop/start at different points between the start and stop cursors, leading to complex visual representation where different rasters end at different times.
TestStep.Result: No UI glitches or errors in the raster plots

TestStep.Action: Files with significantly different lengths may cause alignment issues where the shorter files' raster views end much earlier, leading to large empty spaces in the raster view panel.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Rapid adjustments of the start and stop cursors might cause synchronization issues, resulting in temporary display artifacts or incorrect empty portions being rendered.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Continuous adjustment of the window selector while files are terminating could result in flickering or incomplete updates.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Displaying very short files might cause the empty portion to dominate the raster view, potentially confusing users.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Display glitches might occur if the UI does not handle empty space rendering correctly, especially for very long empty portions.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Interactions near the edges of the raster view, where files terminate, might not trigger proper updates or may cause rendering issues.
TestStep.Result: No problems

TestStep.Action: Scrolling behavior or resizing the raster view might not correctly handle the transition between raster data and empty portions.
TestStep.Result: No problems

Test.JiraSummary: Test The user should be able to permanently delete experiments

TestStep.Action: Open Off-AxIS and create a new experiment.
TestStep.Result: Experiment is created in {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments}}.

TestStep.Action: Add a spike file to the experiment.
TestStep.Result: Folder named {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\[Spike-file-barcode]\[Spike-file-timestamp]}} is created containing the spike file and other files.

TestStep.Action: Right-click->Delete on the experiment in Off-AxIS.
TestStep.Result: * The experiment is removed from the sidebar. * The experiment json file is deleted from the "Workspace\Experiments" folder. * The experiment files (spike file, etc.) are not deleted.

Test.JiraSummary: Test The user should be able to hide experiments, and unhide hidden experiments

TestStep.Action: * Open OffAxIS and create 3 experiments. * Name them One, Two, Three.
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: * Select File > "Show Hidden Experiments. * Right-click → Hide experiment "One".
TestStep.Result: * Experiment "One" doesn’t disappear. * Experiment "One" changes background color to a slightly darker orange to indicate the "hidden" state.

TestStep.Action: Unselect "Show Hidden Experiments".
TestStep.Result: * Experiment "One" disappears. * Experiment "Two" and "Three" remain.

TestStep.Action: Right-click → Hide experiment "Two".
TestStep.Result: * Experiment "Two" disappears. * Experiment "Three" remains.

TestStep.Action: Select "Show Hidden Experiments".
TestStep.Result: * Experiment "One" and "Two" reappear, both with a paler background to indicate their "hidden" state. * "Experiment "Three" remains, not pale.

TestStep.Action: Right-click → Unhide experiment "One".
TestStep.Result: * Experiment "One" becomes brighter/"unpale", the same as Experiment "Three" when selected. White when unselected. * Experiment "Two" remains "pale".

TestStep.Action: Right-click → Unhide experiment "Two".
TestStep.Result: Experiment "Two" becomes brighter/"unpale", the same as Experiment "One" and "Three" when selected. White when unselected.

TestStep.Action: Unselect "Show Hidden Experiments".
TestStep.Result: No experiment disappears. All three remain and not pale.

Test.JiraSummary: Test A user should see all files in an experiment when that experiment is selected

TestStep.Action: * Open OffAxIS and create an experiment. * Name the experiment "MyExperiment".
TestStep.Result: {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments\MyExperiment.json}} is created.

TestStep.Action: Add a spike file to the experiment.
TestStep.Result: * The experiment has a group box with the header "Source Files" listing the spike files that were added. * The files are in a data grid with the following columns: ** *File Name* (_name of the file with extension_) ** *Name* (_name of the file without extension_) ** *Timepoint* (_Read-only: The difference between the start time of this file and the start time of the experiment overall. This should be represented in the largest sensible time units.)_ ** *Reference* (_checkboxes_) ** *Notes* (_empty_)

TestStep.Action: Add a second spike file.
TestStep.Result: The Timepoint should change in reference to the oldest file from the ones added.

TestStep.Action: Edit the display *Name* and *Notes* of the files.
TestStep.Result: * They can be edited. * The changes are reflected in {{MyExperiment.json}}.

TestStep.Action: Edit the *File Name* and *Timepoint*.
TestStep.Result: * They can’t be edited. * No changes are reflected in {{MyExperiment.json}}.

TestStep.Action: Click on the *Reference* checkboxes.
TestStep.Result: * Only one can be checked at a time. * The changes ({{IsReference}}) are reflected in {{MyExperiment.json}}.

TestStep.Action: Resize the OffAxIS window wide and narrow.
TestStep.Result: Long experiment names and notes do not get cut off.

Test.JiraSummary: Test A user should have the ability to add (import) a brand new .spk file to an experiment and remove it

TestStep.Action: * Open OffAxIS and create an experiment. * Name the experiment "MyExperiment".
TestStep.Result: {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments\MyExperiment.json}} is created.

TestStep.Action: * Click on "Add From File…" * Navigate to a folder containing spike files and other files.
TestStep.Result: A file picker appears that if filtered to only show .spk files.

TestStep.Action: Select a spike file.
TestStep.Result: * Spike file is added to the experiment. * Remove button becomes available. * {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments\[spk_barcode][spk_timestamp]}} is created containing a copy of the spike file.

TestStep.Action: Open {{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments\MyExperiment.json}} in a text editor.
TestStep.Result: The {{Barcode}} section lists the barcode of the spike file as shown in OffAxIS.

TestStep.Action: Click on "Add From File…" again.
TestStep.Result: The file picker defaults to the last folder we used to import a .spk file.

TestStep.Action: * Close the file picker. * Select the imported spike file. * Click on Remove.
TestStep.Result: * The file is removed from OffAxIS. * The spike file remains in the workspace ({{C:\ProgramData\Axion BioSystems\OffAxIS\Workspace\Experiments[spk_barcode][spk_timestamp]}}). * The experiment json file is changed to no longer show the spike file listed. (The {{Barcode}} section is empty)

Test.JiraSummary: Test A user should have the ability to hide and show files in the Experiment Setup Panel

TestStep.Action: * Open OffAxIS * Create an experiment add three files.
TestStep.Result: Done.

TestStep.Action: Unselect "Show Hidden Files".
TestStep.Result: * File "Three" disappears. * File "One" and "Two" remain.

TestStep.Action: * Select file "Two". * Click the "Hide" button.
TestStep.Result: * File "Two" disappears. * File "One" remains. * File "Two" does not appear in any other analysis modules or ‘downstream’ modules.

TestStep.Action: Select "Show Hidden Files".
TestStep.Result: * File "Two" and "Three" reappear, both with a paler background to indicate their "hidden" state. * "File "One" remains, not pale.

TestStep.Action: * Select File "Three". * Click "Unhide" button.
TestStep.Result: * File "Three" becomes brighter/"unpale", the same as File "One". * File "Two" remains "pale". * File "Three" reappears in other relevant analysis modules or ‘downstream’ modules.

TestStep.Action: * Select File "Two". * Click "Unhide" button.
TestStep.Result: * File "Two" becomes brighter/"unpale", the same as File "One" and "Three". * File "Two" reappears in other relevant analysis modules or ‘downstream’ modules.

TestStep.Action: Unselect "Show Hidden Files".
TestStep.Result: No file disappears. All three remain and not pale.

TestStep.Result: Files added to newly created experiment.

Test.JiraSummary: Test The user should be able to align files relative to each other in a multi-file Experiment

TestStep.Action: Open an experiment with more than one file
TestStep.Result: # When more than one file is present in an experiment, the ‘raster preview’ portion of the ‘Window Selector’ widget will change to a ‘multi-track’ control that permits aligning files relative to each other. # Each track should show some representation of the entire file it’s covering. This should be one of ({color:#ff5630}*This is still in design as of 6/5/2024)*{color}{color:#ff5630}:{color} Stim Tags Network Bursts Spike Histogram # Each file in the experiment should get a ‘row’ in the widget, that has the user-defined name of the file present in it. # The order of the rows must correspond to the order determined in the File Grid on the Experiment Setup page. # Each file track should default to the far left of the available space, so that each file is aligned based on the ‘second 0’ timestamp of its data. !xray-attachment://578b7261-0257-42e9-ad51-bdbc8c6645d4|width=999,height=154!

TestStep.Action: Move one of the tracks with the mouse (click 'n drag. This method is recommended for making large adjustments with the alignment)
TestStep.Result: # Moving a track through the available track space should ‘realign’ that file relative to the others in the experiment # The visible rasters should update to show the portion of the file that is now between the window selector cursors. # *The raster update should not trigger until the track is released*

TestStep.Action: Select another track and move it via arrow keys (This method is recommended for fine tuning the alignment after the click 'n drag which makes larger adjustments more easily)
TestStep.Result: Each click of the arrow key should trigger a raster update

TestStep.Action: Resize the application window making it both larger and smaller
TestStep.Result: # When the window is resized, the file ‘tracks’ should change size and scale to accommodate the new window size # The relative alignment should not change, and # The rasters should not have to update

TestStep.Action: Remove a spk file
TestStep.Result: The file should no longer appear in the File Alignment Widget The raster updates correctly

TestStep.Action: Look at the track for the longest file in the experiment and the smaller files too
TestStep.Result: # The longest file in the experiment should take up exactly half of the available horizontal space in the widget, not accounting for margins and borders. # The other, smaller files in the experiment must be sized relative to this larger file. For example, if the largest file is 60 seconds long, and the next-largest is 45 seconds long, the track for the 45-second file must be ¾ the size of the 60 second track. A 30 second file must be ½ the size of the 60 second track.

TestStep.Action: If necessary, move the start/stop cursors so that a file track starts, stops or both starts and stops inside the window
TestStep.Result: # The raster(s) from the file(s) must also ‘end’ somewhere within their rasters, so that the remaining data is properly aligned with the other files. # The remaining portion of the raster not covered by the file should be empty. _In the screenshot below, note the file ‘Baseline But Another One’ which has some ‘empty space’ in the window, and therefore has some empty space in the rasters in screen._ !xray-attachment://7eb616d9-f407-40f2-8d44-f992aea0aba1|width=1032,height=673!

Test.JiraSummary: Test Report metric reprocessing progress

TestStep.Action: # Create/open an experiment # Add 08052024-ScheduledRecordings(000).spk to the experiment # Select All Wells in the platemap # Open the Raster plot # Using the anchors on the window selector change the window start/stop time as close as you can get to: ## Window Start: 4 ## Window End: 10 # Open the Metric plot # Select a Metric from the list # Click "Reprocess"
TestStep.Result: # Since the experiment start/end time was was changed from the default, the "Reprocess" button is visible # Since the experiment has only one file, the progress bar should reflect the percent of the selected segment of 6 seconds being processed. # Text label "Calculating metrics…" should be displayed above the progress bar.

TestStep.Action: # Add 08052024-ScheduledRecordings(001).spk to the experiment # Select All Wells # Do not change Start/End times # Do not change the Offset values for either spike file # Click "Reprocess" in the Barplot
TestStep.Result: # Since the experiment experiment has multiple files, the progress bar should reflect the percent average of the selected segments being processed in both files. # Text label "Calculating metrics…" should be displayed above the progress bar.

TestStep.Action: # Add the remaining 8 spike files (002) - (0008) to the experiment # Do not change Start/End times # Edit the Offset value for each file, ## (000) Offset = 1 ## (001) Offset = 2 ## … ## (009) Offset = 10 # Click "Reprocess" in the Barplot
TestStep.Result: # Since the experiment experiment has multiple files, the progress bar should reflect the percent average of the selected segments being processed in all 10 files. # Text label "Calculating metrics…" should be displayed above the progress bar.

TestStep.Action: # Change the start and end time in the raster plot using the textbox not the slider 2:55 and 14.25 respectively # Do not modify the offsets # Click "Reprocess" in the bar plot
TestStep.Result: # the progress bar should reflect the percent average of the selected segments being processed in all 10 files. # Text label "Calculating metrics…" should be displayed above the progress bar.
